My father-in-law was like that. We had radically different tastes when it came to films (and pretty much everything else, in fact). When we were at his place, and he wanted to watch something on TV, I kept my mouth shut, even though I thought it was the biggest idiocy on the planet (he had a fondness of German romantic made-for-TV films). When he was at our place and we wanted to watch a film, he would not stop ranting about how stupid that film was, until we told him to shut the fuck up.

There doesn't seem to be much "proper" science behind acupuncture. According to [this article](https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/an-industry-of-worthless-acupuncture-studies/)
carefully controlled scientific studies consistently show that it does not matter where you stick the needles or even if you insert needles (as opposed to just poking the skin with dull needles, or retracting needles, or even tooth picks). To further support this conclusion, the perceived effectiveness of acupuncture does not depend on the degree of training or experience of the acupuncturist (so whatever they are learning has no effect), but only upon how warm and nice they are to the patient. In short, acupuncture is an elaborate placebo.

WRITING.TITLE: Someone at ELI5 asking about the "science" of acupuncture.
WRITING.TEXT: Here's the thread https://www.reddit.com/r/explainlikeimfive/comments/5iy1qi/eli5_the_science_behind_accupuncture/

What I've read is that the effect is not due to acupuncture itself, but to the fact that you required to stay still and relaxed for some time, which may help to relax some of the muscles, etc. that cause you pain. Or something along those lines. In other words, it's no better than a massage or a hot tub

I had exactly the same problem at secondary school in Argentina. We had a teacher for whom anything that was not in her textbook was wrong.
Thanks for that explanation. I wholeheartedly agree with you. More. and better, research is warranted.
Fair enough. The trials, in any case, were conducted in different groups of people, which could explain the conflicting results, right?

But what if teaching philosophy doesn't end in indoctrination (for lack of a better word)? What if a good teacher can present it (within few sanctioned flavours) in a way that will pique the curiosity of the pupils, who would then try to learn more by themselves? It happens with other subjects, and even in your daily life: you are exposed to something new, interesting and you want to learn and experience more about it.

It's not only one study, the article cites a review of 24 studies that had different problems and, therefore, don't provide any useful evidence, like patients' drop out, as the WebMD article you linked mentions.

Having read the article, the "cheaper" bit seems solid. The "healthier" bit, however, only seems to apply to China, that has different standards than in Europe or North America.
But what about nutritious value. I'd love to see some research showing the differences between the same produce grown in a field, in a garden, in a greenhouse and in hydroponic systems.
I think in this context would mean "a good tool for teaching/education (in general)", or something along those lines, if you know what I mean.

OK, let me see.
Airlines were still offering smoking flights as recently as the late 90s (source: I travelled quite a bit back then), though only in some long-haul routes, maybe to and from Japan, IIRC. All the rest were non-smoking by then. Was it self-regulatory? I don't know, in any case it's good because you're stuck several hours on a plane, without the possibility of even opening a window.
Also doctors used to advocate smoking,
Some doctors did, and likely bribed by the industry to deny the scientific consensus that goes back to the 1920, IIRC. It's almost as if a doctor today recommended a diet of donuts and coke.

The difference is that a paywall will prevent access to the contents unless I pay. Shitty business model perhaps, but nonetheless fair.
Relying on donations is a safer bet than putting ads that many people will block regardless. If your work is good, and the word gets around, there will more people willing to donate, at least a couple of Euro, than to click on an ad. Besides, there are also ways to put ads that will get around an ad-blocker (unless the user actively blocks it).
In that case, the ban should apply to all working places, as they did in the UK, IIRC.
No, not really. There are places I don't go to because of the food, the decoration, the prices, the music, the service. Smoking or non-smoking is just another factor.

True, but let's say a blog gives you their content for free hoping that you or any other user will click on ad.
Then it'd be a very shitty business model, because the contents itself remains free access and I've no obligation to click on any ad. It'd be more effective to put a "Donate" button.

And a great number of them are smokers themselves. In any case, they can change jobs, can't they? There are tonnes of other people working in less than sanitary conditions and nobody is calling on a ban.

I fully agree. The reason I installed adblocking software was because the ads became a) a risk, b) way too intrusive. I don't mind banners that aren't hosted in third party servers and have no animation or sound, anymore than I mind printed ads on a magazine.
However, I don't agree with your piracy analogy. In order to see a film or a cable TV show I have to either pay ticket/fee/buy media or wait until it gets broadcast on network TV. In contrast, if I want to read a non-paywalled electronic version of a newspaper or magazine, I don't have to pay for it, nor am I under any obligation to click on any of the ads.
All that being said, though, enforcing a ban on adblocking software would be every bit as easy as getting rid of torrent sites or clients.
If I'm not wrong, the legality is only being questioned by a small number of people, who happen to be some of those affected by the use pf ad blockers.
Hubo polmica, pero hoy sera muchsimo peor.

The difference between someone making noise at 3 in the morning and smoking in a pub is that you can't choose not to hear the noise, A pub, on the other hand? You don't have to walk in, do you? You can go to another one, or stay home.

I think it also depends a lot on the person and the conspiracy.
The other I found out that a guy I sometimes meet at one my regular pub believes in chemtrails. And he was showing pictures of contrails he had taken with his mobile the day before.
I asked him who he thought was behind that and why were they doing it, also whether he had ever considered the type of infrastructure that something like that would need, and that kind thing. He responded with the usual "but there are more of them lines now than back in the day!". I explained him that of course, because there are a lot more planes flying around and above the country (I live in the Czech Republic) than there were back in the day.
I don't know if I was able to change his mind, but at least he shut up, and I may have planted a seed of doubt, and I'd be happy if that turns out the be case. And I believe that is the case, it's a person by person "fight" (for lack of a better word) and, more often than not, you will have to make do with just planting a seed of doubt.
It's a business decision like any other and one has to assume the owners have made it in their best interest.

About Prague:
The best place to get your fix of Bohemian brews is the Czech capital. Although the Pilsener style originated in the town of Plze, Prague is a great place to enjoy it, whether youre on a shoestring budget or living it up. Dont miss **U Flecku**(1) a tavern thats been brewing beer for over 500 years! This 1200-seater spot **rarely has a seat readily available** (2), but it is worth the wait. The dark lager they serve up is full of frothy, chocolately goodness, and the chaos of the tourists, waiters, and accordion players just adds to the charm. Other specialty brews include the **St. Thomas dark beer at The Augustine, which is even today made by the practicing friars who live in the vicinity** (3), and the hilltop Strahov Monastery. One thing you should know before hitting up the City of Spires is **the word pivovar which translates to beer bar**(4). Trust us, itll hold you in good stead.
(1) It's U Fleku
(2) Maybe in the evenings, otherwise you can walk in a grab a seat during most of the day. The beer is great, the place's a tourist trap.
(3) I would love to know where they go that from, because it's utter bullshit. The brewery was shut down in the 1950s, and even then I doubt there were any monks brewing. The pub operated until 2002 or 3 and now the site is a fancy hotel and the dark beer available is made by Matuka, and it's his standard dark lager.
(4) No! "Pivovar" is Czech for "Brewery".
I didn't bother with the rest of the cities. My bet is that Karina hasn't visited Prague, and probably any of those towns.

WRITING.TEXT: Seguro, pero no se puede comparar a una reina de belleza de 122 kilos con un deportista discapacitado.

El tipo que est jugando con petardos, uno que corre picadas y otro perdi una pierna po no dejrsela tratar, no son muy vivos, no?
El deportista discapacitado, ms all del grado de su discapacidad y el nivel de competencia en el que participe, tiene que entrenar, si quiere ganar, tiene que ser mejor que los otros (incluso, si lo que decs sobre los ciegos es cierto, que quizs lo es). Va a tener que correr ms rpido, va a tener que tirar el disco ms lejos, va a tener que ser fs fuerte, etc.
Yo no estoy diciendo que la mina esta es pelotuda, no la conozco, pero estoy casi seguro que su estilo de vida no es el ms sano. No alcanz ese grado de obesidad de un da para el otro y la gentica podr jugar su papel, pero al fin y al cabo, el control sobre lo que coms y no, lo tens vos. La solucin en este caso es simple, morf menos, movete ms. Lo cual no quiere decir que sea fcil, como con toda adiccin.
En cualquier caso, el deportista discapactiado difcilmente pueda curar su discapacidad. La mina esta, s podra curarse, si quiere.

Y justamente por eso que digo que "en la mayora de los casos". Conozco gente que qued discapacitada porque se cay de un caballo, se apoy en una baranda que estaba mal agarrado y se cay al piso de abajo; otros que nacieron as. Pero ms all de eso, e incluso si la discapacidad es el resultado de ser pelotudo /como tus ejemplos), el hecho es que si participan en una competencia deportiva, estn todos sujetos a las mismas reglas objetivas y gana el mejor. Para llegar ah, tienen que entrenar y cuidarse, como cualquier otro deportista.
En contraste, ac tens una mina que est enferma porque come mucho y se mueve poco (y s, la responsabilidad, si es adulta, es de ella; es bien sabido ya, y desde hace mucho, que ser obeso no es sano, y a esta piba nadie le est obligando a ponerle otra cuchara de dulce de leche al flan) y la premian por "ser la ms linda" (la ms linda segn quin?), o sea, la estn alentando a seguir gorda, a seguir enferma.
I love how the fucker looks at the camera before charging.

No pods comparar. En primer lugar, porque en la mayora de los casos, la discapacidad no es el resultado de una adiccin o un estilo de vida nocivo. En segundo, porque los deportistas discapacitados saben bien que no son "normales", ni quieren serlo; buscan superarse a s mismos y su condicin, compitiendo todos bajo las mismas reglas objetivas, y que gane el mejor. A la gorda esta le estn dando un premio por estar enferma.
